required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Drug Eluting Ballon Versus Stenting in the Superficial Femoral Artery
clinical_study.official_title: Drug Eluting Balloon Angioplasty Versus Nitinol Stent Implantation in the Superficial Femoral Artery

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate whether the results of drug eluting balloon are equivalent to the Nitinol stent implantation in the Superficial Femoral Artery.

primary_outcome.description: Evaluations will be conducted after 3, 6 and 12 months of the procedure. The ultrasonographic evaluation of the degree of stenosis will use the Systolic Velocity Index (division of the velocity of flow at the point of greatest stenosis by the velocity of flow in normal prior segment). Rates higher than 2.4 indicate stenosis greater than 50%

secondary_outcome.description: Change in classification from Rutherford evaluated in 3, 6 and 12 months.
Change in the Ankle braquial Index evaluated in 3, 6 and 12 months
Target Lesion Revascularization rate evaluated in 3, 6 and 12 months
Stent fracture rate evaluated in 3, 6 and 12 months
Major amputation defined as amputation that requires prosthesis
Acute myocardial infarct rate evaluated in 3, 6 and 12 months
Death rate evaluated in 3, 6 and 12 months

intervention.description: Angioplasty with Drug eluting balloon after pre dilatation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients over 18 years with critical lower limb ischemia,
- Ruhtherford 3 or higher,
- with angiographic documentation of greater than 70% or occlusion in the superficial femoral artery,
- with a maximum extension of 10 cm stenosis.
- The popliteal artery and at least one leg artery must be patent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnancy,
- thrombophilia,
- coagulation disorders,
- presence of active or recent bleeding,
- severe allergy to iodinated contrast,
- renal or hepatic disease,
- acute limb ischemia,
- prior surgical bypass or angioplasty (with or without stent) on the target artery,
- obstructive disease (stenosis> 50%) of the aortoiliac segment ipsilateral to the target (if the aortoiliac is pre-treated, the patient may be included)
